shift and talk to you about why it makes sense to choose that as a platform for analytics and dereck's going to talk

interesting stuff ahead so what is red shrift so red shft is Amazon spab scale data warehouse it's
fully SQL and we conceived of this with sort of three principles in mind we wanted to build something that was very
simple uh that was fast and that was cheap so let's take that apart uh by
simple what I mean is it should be easy for you as a customer it should be super easy to just understand to know how to
use it and very easy to interact with every aspect of the system so let me
give you an example uh prior to launch we launched on Valentine's Day last year prior to launch uh we had a goal of uh
you know you should be able to start up a data warehous create a red cluster when the same time it takes to go buy a book on
amazon.com and that seemed kind of ambitious at the time but we've been working on it and at this point we can
create cre a r of cluster on an average we see the create times is around 2 and a half to 3 minutes so you know pretty
close and we want to just take that Beyond just creation right we want it to be easy to query easy to copy data into
red shift and uh easy in the sense you don't have to worry about all the failures that happened behind the scenes
and singularly just focus on getting dat getting value out of your data and leveraging your data vhouse uh that's
sort of what Simplicity is all about the second thing is speed people want think really fast so I get the opportunity to
talk to a good set of my customers um every week on a lot of customer calls
and I'm yet to come across a conversation where someone's telling me okay viya please loow on my queries by
20% it's just too fast that never happens right there's just more and more data to deal with and fewer hours to
Crunch through them and get your reporting done um and so retu was built with as an MPP system so it can scale
out and it is built as a columnist system both of which gives you tremendous speed and the third aspect is
cheap again doesn't need all that much motivation uh we we entered the industry
a year and a half ago and we wanted to make this offering such that one didn't have to make very tough choices between
what data to keep and what data to let go because a lot of the data actually does not make its way to the data
warehouse um so we priced this so you can create a rft cluster for as low as
$1,000 per terabyte per year of managed storage this is is managed and compressed uh th000 per
year so that's the very quick overview of what it's all about I want to dig just a little bit into the architecture
so we are a clustered uh architecture uh we have one leader node and any number of compute nodes you get to pick how
many compute nodes you want in the system and this entire thing is within Amazon's HPC Network we use a 10 gig
minimally over subscribed Network internally um and the leader node serves three functions the leader it's
responsible for acting as a sequ end point to all the clients outside so all your bi tools uh ETL tools anything that
wants to connect to Red shift connects through an odbc or a jdbc connection using standard post SQL drivers uh
through the leader node nobody outside can actually connect to any of the compute nodes for security purposes now
the leader node also stores all the metadata for the service so it stores all the catalog information system
tables Etc and furthermore it's responsible for taking the incoming SQL query creating the most optimal query
execution plan and generating the code required to actually execute that query at the compute nodes so that's a leader
node the compute nodes themselves uh is where your data actually gets stored this is where we put all the bits and
it's responsible for executing the the code that comes from the leader node for query processing and it's a columnus
storage again it's columnar because we want to minimize iio there's a lot of data that needs to be brought in and out
so in a column store we only pick out the columns that are relevant for the query on hand and bring them in greatly
redu as IO and it's local storage it's direct attached storage so we get a pretty wide pipe to move data around uh
the other characteristic of the compute nodes is just that it is uh it is a scaleout system so all the major
operations all the really intensive operations happen in parallel note to node parallel whether you're loading
from S3 or coming in from EMR or Dynamo DB or just doing an SS into the node it
all happens in parall and what that really means is if you add another node you get better
performance uh the nodes again we offer two instance types for the nodes you can go with magnetic storage or ssds
depending on what your workload is and what your requirements are uh the the hdds or the magnet DW ones you can start
at 2 terabytes and go all the way to two petabytes a single two paby cluster with
128 nodes and um in this case it's magnetic storage so it's lower than ssds
with ssds you can start with a lower smaller data set size you can start at 160 gigs and go all the way to 356
terabytes and the choice between the two is really a trade-off between price and performance so the ssds are five and a
half times more expensive and 10 to 15 times faster so it really depends on your data set size and uh your slas
around how fast you want things to go I just want to quickly touch on how
we deal with durability and failures because we are a managed service so you might wonder what are we managing so
with respect to durability um we have a couple of things every time you store a bite in red shift there is one primary
copy that makes it there is a secondary in-cluster copy that gets made synchronously and there's a third copy
that goes to S3 asynchronously so you have three copies every time and the backups that we do are automatic
continuous and incremental meaning when you create a cluster we automatically start backing things up and it happens
continuously as you make changes to your data it uh every new new block that gets
added gets transferred to S3 for a backup and we do it incrementally meaning we don't redundantly store data
when you're dealing with paby scale you don't want to waste storage so we we are smart about figuring out what is the Delta change store it and then chain the
blocks in such a way that we can come back to a consistent point in time image for your database so that's the that's
about uh durability uh on the side of uh failures
in the case of local failure so for example you might have a single dis fail or a node failure what we have available
to us is lots of healthy Hardware because you know this is that's what the cloud is all about and we also have
three copies of your data so between the two we are able to get you to a healthy state if there is an a level failure you
still have a backup in S3 that you can resurrect to another a in the same region at any time when you do so and
create a cluster with that backup you're going to be up and running running with a cluster in about 3 minutes uh what we
do internally is Page in data as in when your queries come in and H and serve
those queries so the performance is slightly degraded but end of the day you have a cluster up and running very
quickly and if you have a region level failure what you could do is set up cross region backups in which case we
actually move the uh backup uh blocks not just to the local S3 but also to a
bucket in a remote another another S3 in a different region and so if you had a region level failure you can actually
bring that up in a in a new cluster and get going so that just gives you some
options about uh when you think about availability so let me then touch on why
this is an interesting platform particularly for healthcare I think the first bullet you guys know better than I
do uh but essentially the the healthcare industry as a whole is going through some sort of Big Data Revolution or Big
Data reinvention as uh the Phillips person mentioned this morning there's just so much more data that being
generated and become becoming publicly available uh there's always been historical R&D data and medical
databases and now add to that data that's coming in from you know sensory devices holding information about vital
stats or whether it is uh digitized patient records and then there's lots of government regulations wherein uh
there's more transparency around uh the the data from clinical trials as well as
insurance coverage Etc On and On In Parallel the healthcare costs have been going up up and so there is a need for
the industry as a whole to figure out how you leverage all of this information all of this available to you and figure
out how you can drive better outcomes and so that's really the need and why is
retro suitable well there is a lot of data and if one thing that be became
clear from the other three slides I just talked about we really are geared towards dealing with paby scale uh data
issues and data analytics and doing that at a in a cost effective fashion you know th000 terabytes ,000 per terabyte
per year and we also give multiple options with respect to how you can create and manage your clusters uh you
can do one big cluster you can do multiple um uh you can do multiple
clusters and the cost does not change because of that uh and finally the other big reason is this is certainly a domain
where security matters a great deal security and compliance and with red
shift we've actually treated security as a first class citizen right from day one
when we launched last year we launched with encryption and uh we've always believed
that having all the security uh features in play will be a big needle mover for for us especially with our more security
conscious customers such as Healthcare and financial so let me spend a little bit of time about why we are secure so
there are two aspects to this on one side we have encryption and then we have auditing uh so on the encryption side
data gets encrypted at the source uh when it's in transit and when and it makes it into the cluster so at the
source whether you're S3 or Dynamo or where you're coming from you need to give us the key so that we decrypt that
and make sense of the data when it's in route coming to Red shift whether it's internally through
AWS or outside we use SSL so it's encrypted and rout in fact recently we added support for elliptic curve Diffy
Helman with emal keys which affords perfect forward security and what that really means is if there was somebody
sitting there uh grabbing all the encrypted traffic and for some reason if the long-term secret is compromised at a
future point in time they will still not be able to use that to decrypt the traffic that was already captured so
it's a nice feature and if you think about once data makes it into the red offt cluster we encrypt every single
block with a with a different key within the cluster and then we use a scheme of
um uh hierarchical keys and envelope encryption uh to to to encrypt the keys
for the blocks with another key with another key and it's a hierarchical thing and the reason we do it this way
is you don't want to go ahead and um rotate the block keys because that would that would require re-encrypting your
entire data set which is huge so what you end up doing instead is rotating the other levels of keys in this and you
could even do it so that the top level key actually has to be uh given to us by
your HSM HSM may be either local or on Prem but essentially we would have to come to you for every time we want to
access the data in the cluster to get get that key at that point in time so that we may go on and make sense of your
data so lots of work we spend a lot of time in getting these features in and
working on security and staying on top of what's coming out um on the auditing side we audit all the database activity
uh in an S3 bucket of your choice that's all the DML stuff who accesses what tables Etc on the API front we are
integrated with cloud trail that's a AWS service that authentically manages all
the access that has happened to the API who access what API Etc um and so and of course we leverage
bpc and security groups and all the regular stuff uh so with that we've been able to get certified for a whole host
of regulations including Hippa which might be relevant uh for this
group so the last chart um I just wanted to point out here the only thing is we
don't exist in isolation uh data warehouse is part of a life cycle of things that you do typically the common

move it to some sort of a compute uh E2 or EMR where you cleanse the data you summarize it you validate it and then

your use cases also start to get more difficult as you as you take on more and more uh into the platform uh so one of
the things that that was really challenging uh for us in this phase of our growth was running queries so you
saw in the demo we were really driving that real time realtime use case and um
that was getting really tough because the data volumes were growing um as you can see we let people sort of
arbitrarily run queries and put questions together and we didn't want to limit them right every customer we
talked to had different things that they cared about um different custom data that they had um different parts of our
data that they wanted to to consume so uh it wasn't the sort of thing where we could just say well you can only query
these bu fields and we'll make some indexes and then everything will be fine that just wasn't going to meet the use case so we had to do something different
than just issuing queries to a database engine and so the way that we solved this was by developing a technology uh
that we call fft or fast fine transform um fine being our uh our name for for
queries um so this is sort of a a highlevel view um of of how we of how we
process queries using fft um it it's a little bit uh it's a little bit more comp at behind the scenes this gives you
the general idea um so typically when you want to run a query uh you put together a bunch of criteria um put it
together in a syntactically correct manner ship it off to the database engine and hope for the best right um
and you can be really really smart about this uh if you own all the queries and um if you run the databases you can say
okay I can run explain plan and definitively says it's going to run the query in this particular way um I can
create an index to cover that everything's going to be great until next week when your data changes and the
statistics update and then the query Optimizer makes a different decision and everything gets slow in that corner of the application so uh in the best case
the database engines do a terrific job but in the worst case things can get really really bad um and so our goal
with fft was to potentially and not in all cases but potentially take a little bit of a hit on the best case um but
really really do well uh in the worst case scenarios so how do we do it so we take the query and instead of just
shipping it off to the database and running it we actually pull apart every single individual criteria and we run
those independently uh and yes we can run those in parallel which also helps as you as you scale out your data layer
so uh so once we've run each fragment of this query independently then we we
store the result so you can see on the left side um I've got a list of numbers representing the the IDS um the unique
IDs um for that particular Slice on the right side I have the unique IDs for that particular slice so
great why do that right that sounds like that's a little bit more complicated and some of those lists could be pretty long
right um yes and we have some some fancy fancy ways of controlling the list length by doing inversions and things
like that um but the really key point to remember here is that we cach these so
once we've run one part of the query once we remember it so that the next time you run that query it's already
done and so that's a really important aspect you saw that kind of iterative workflow
in the in the segmentation UI that's really what we're targeting here uh so you're going to be reusing a lot of
different pieces and so so this is really well targeted to those use cases um so great so we've got these lists of
numbers but we're trying to get the count how does this actually work um so you can see here that um it simply does
an in memory merge all the lists are stored in memory at all times uh an in memory merge as you might expect is
extremely fast um so we find all all of the matching elements and then we build the resultant Set uh in some cases we
will even cash these intermediate sets um for for large um large data sets particularly when they have inversions
and other filters applied um because it can be a little bit expensive um but once you have that final list you can
just take the count so so obviously the count is three so this is great um but
but people who have uh thrown caching at uh at at performance problems in the past might be thinking yeah caching is
great and then data changes and everything goes back to where you started um fortunately we thought about
that so um one of the key things that we built into fft is the ability to track data changing in the system uh as it
changes so when we issue an insert uh through the through the system that goes
through an API call uh in all cases whether it's an ETL um or somebody uh
uploading a spreadsheet through the application itself uh no matter how the data gets in it goes through this engine
and uh and we analyze every single change that happens in the system and we generate what we call a data Delta um so
in this case somebody's adding a new record um that has 99 and some particular values so we capture that
data Delta and then within the fft engine we evaluate that data Delta against every single cast list that we
may have to find out if it may uh be invalidating that particular thing um we do a minimal query a one row query uh to
ensure because we can't always um uh know with certainty um if if if it
actually is impacted and once we've done that very fast one row query we can confidently just insert it into the set
and uh and so as the data changes we don't have to rerun that whole query to rebuild the list so the lists are constantly dynamically changing uh and
again anytime somebody um ask that same question it's nearly instantaneous um so
so fft has been been really a fantastic piece of technology for our segmentation
